generation: Another week flew by. I drove past the new house yesterday—the front window was covered in boxes. We may get the keys at closing; I’m so excited. If all goes well, we’ll be set to close a week from Wednesday. I stayed up past 3:00 AM watching movies with Bethany. Lately, we’ve been watching a lot. Last night, we saw *Thirteen*—every mother of a teen should watch it. It was better than expected. Then we watched *Gigli*; just as bad as the media said, but we had to see for ourselves.

Summer TV used to be a dead zone full of repeats, but now there are two great new shows I’ve been watching religiously. *Blow Out*—the gayest concept ever with seemingly zero gay people in sight. Hairstylist Jonathan Antin wants to open a second location for his popular West Hollywood salon, this time in Beverly Hills. Normally, no one would care—certainly not me—but while flipping through channels, I caught a glimpse of Jonathan, equally narcissistic and dull, staring at an empty space on Rodeo Dr. and declaring (loudly), 'I’m going to build the greatest salon in history!' I was hooked. Not since Rocco has such a moron made for compelling TV.

What a week... My right shoulder has tendonitis, right under the shoulder blade. Moving my arm too much—especially while using a computer mouse—is agonizing. I overdid it updating my website and working online, so now I can barely move it. Drawing feels impossible, and lack of sleep worsens the pain. I’m not too happy, but I’ll recover. My mom’s surgery went well—her eyesight has improved slightly. She sees fuzzy shapes and colors but remains mostly blind. Hopefully, her vision will fully return soon.

Kindness of strangers... Attempted laundry today with the kids in tow and realized how quickly the simplest tasks can become an ordeal. I also discovered how incredibly kind strangers can be for no reason other than their own goodwill. Trust me—it wasn’t about ulterior motives. I had kid drool all over me and wore my 'wash-day' outfit... Plus, I’m not entirely sure I’ll ever bathe again, so there wasn’t even an olfactory incentive! Currently, I’m writing this post while watching No Doubt’s music videos, seated at my desk.

So, I ended up watching *Joe Schmo 2* again tonight.

Remind me, what did I write about before this? Or, a continuation of the 'Is this a date?' saga. After the awkward lunch, my confidence wavered, and I forgot to share a key detail. Before Pat arrived, Dustin started praising him, mentioning how he wanted to find him a girlfriend. As I listened and nodded, it dawned on me that we were focusing more on setting Pat up than having a normal conversation with a stranger over lemonade. I excused myself to the bathroom, looked in the mirror, and wondered: Am I being pawned off to his friend? Is this really happening?

I would like everyone to think before they act. In fact, I'd like every single person in the world to think before getting out of bed each morning and commit to staying thoughtful all day. If they're unwilling, I'd prefer they just stay in bed and drift into eternal sleep. I'm exhausted by foolishness. I'm not the smartest person alive, but I'm not discussing complex matters—just basic reasoning. It's fair to criticize sheer stupidity. Let’s focus on a few types today and save the rest for another time. Sound good? Great.

Went to The Cove to see Supernothing—they were great as always, and got to hang with Tiago. Saturday: work, then out with Joe and Rach; met up with Steve, Tiago, and Tom. I think that **monopoly** has run **its** course in my life, and I vow never to lay my hands on that **darn** iron (not a hot one, but the piece in the game) again. Tonight, Andy beat me by a few dollars and won the **friggin'** game—or maybe I let him win, since he’s leaving soon and I wanted him to feel good on his last night here. Well... Today's been a long day. We drove home from Indiana, and I’ll have to be selective about what I write—I don’t have the energy for much. First, camp was incredible, even better than I expected. God’s been working in my life lately, and it’s amazing. I’ve turned over a new leaf, I suppose. Anyway, back to the start: we arrived at the Twiggs’ house Friday evening and stayed until leaving for camp Monday. We mostly went to the fair, church, a parade, Walmart, and watched movies.

Today is my last day of summer vacation! Waaaaaa! I have a dentist appointment at 9, which I hate, but I'd rather get it over with than reschedule during my surgery rotation. I'm nervous, scared, jittery—basically every synonym for "I don’t want to go" applies. School will be a whole new challenge. As a perfectionist, I excel at everything, but starting new things is tough. I hate being a pawn (like I told Cassie: 'I’ll be the pawn moving like a knight') and not knowing what’s ahead.

Arun Shourie discusses how the current governor of Uttar Pradesh had warned, as early as 1996, about the looming threat of a 'third Islamic state' emerging in the subcontinent. T.V. Rajeswar, former head of the Intelligence Bureau and now Uttar Pradesh governor, predicted this grave danger in a series of articles published in *The Hindustan Times* back in 1996. Shourie raises a pertinent question: Does knowing that Rajeswar—not him or Mr. Advani—wrote these warnings lend them credibility? Or does it suggest Rajeswar is a closet communalist unfit to remain governor?

All of a sudden, for the past two days, I’ve been overwhelmed by terrible exhaustion—bone-deep fatigue. Last evening, I went home and slept until my mother called me around eight thirty. When I woke, it was dark, and without the lights on, I couldn’t tell the time or date for a moment—just my mother’s voice in the darkness as I struggled to grasp reality. Wondering why I feel so drained... Lovely weather this morning. It was drizzling when I arrived, though I hear it’s been raining in Calcutta for three days.

Last night was terrible. I discarded the sweater I was knitting after completing only 14 inches. I lost around $10 worth of yarn (at $8 per skein). By the armholes, there were too many stitches, and the mohair kept tangling as I worked, making frogging ineffective. The yarn kept breaking. Uncharacteristically, I didn’t swear—just gloomily unraveled it while listening to *Sex and the City* (thanks, library!). Eventually, I gave up and tossed it. At least I learned a lot attempting this sweater.

Last night in class, we discussed the week’s assigned reading, *Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World* by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter explores "implacement," while the second examines "displacement." Casey argues that modern culture prioritizes time as the organizing force—evident in phrases like "running out of time" or "saving time." He suggests centering culture around place instead, fostering a more grounded community. (This is a rough summary—just in case my professor or classmates read this.) So far, this book has truly captivated me.

I know I didn’t. Well, fine—I tuned in briefly. This colossal waste of time was orchestrated by Republicans, furious that Democrats wouldn’t rubber-stamp four of Bush’s extreme judicial picks, staging a multi-day tantrum for political points. Never mind that Democrats have already approved 168 of Bush’s nominees—no, that’s insufficient for power-hungry Republicans, who somehow believe they have a mandate for such theatrics.

This was a great weekend. I enjoyed a lot of God's green leaf, and after too long, I finally listened to Nevermore (something I should’ve started much earlier). I also read extensively, finishing three books: Bruce Sterling’s *Heavy Weather*, Larry Niven’s *World of Ptavvs*, and Octavia Butler’s *Parable of the Sower*. *Heavy Weather* was an engaging cyberpunk journey through a near-future USA ravaged by climate chaos and anarchy. Though clever, well-paced, and convincing, I didn’t walk away deeply moved by the story or characters. Both are well-crafted and vivid—it’s a good book, just not a great one.

Because this is the aftermath. The first week back from practicum was a struggle, but only in the second week has the smoke truly begun to clear. Post-practicum trauma was a hidden epidemic now coming to light. I was overwhelmed, but meeting the course coordinator helped me release my burden, preventing another student from enduring such a pedagogically deficient practicum school. Yesterday (Monday), I met another distressed classmate determined to warn the next student assigned to her school. I calmed her and suggested we approach the administrator first.

Fall 1974: I was attempting—for what felt like the 13th time—to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then, nor am I now, a math person. I despise math. I’m math-phobic. You get the idea. As I struggled to grasp algebra, the doorbell rang. I set my book aside and answered the door. No one was there. Perfect. I returned to my studies, and just as a glimmer of understanding surfaced, the doorbell rang again. Bam—my breakthrough vanished. I checked the door, and again, no one. Just what a struggling student needs: an uninvited prankster.

This past week has been exhausting. I spent Tuesday through Thursday moving to my new classroom, which is larger and closer to my grade-level team—key factors as I prepare for the year. Had I known about the move earlier, I would have discarded unused books and supplies. Instead, everything came with me, so this week involved moving, unpacking, and purging. I’m grateful to my teammate Jill, who was still teaching in my old room this month. She and her wonderful students moved nearly everything for me!

"You can’t escape it: a part of you will always live in me. Even if I never bore your child, even if we were never married, even if we were never an official pair... I loved you deeply, and to this day, that feeling echoes in my heart. I’ll forever cherish the few nights we shared, hearts and limbs entwined, lost in the salty darkness by the beach... or a kiss in the rain. When sorrow pierces my heart, you’ll be there—that piece of you... bleeding the eternal love that once lived in me... and still remains... For her.

I'm uncomfortable. Investigative reporting feels very wrong to me—or rather, the article I'm working on and its consequences don't sit well with me. Perhaps it's because I lack conviction, unable to fully grasp the passion behind it, the drive to question. I grew up in a country where asking questions was forbidden. They'd shoot or jail you for it under internal security acts. I'm unaccustomed to this freedom of speech, to voicing doubts openly. Admittedly, I'm not the easiest person to get along with.

We had an outing yesterday with my colleagues from the bank. We visited Guintubdan in La Carlota—a first for most of us. The trek to the falls took about 30 minutes, leaving us breathless, but we persevered. The water was icy cold, numbing our bodies. We stayed briefly before heading to nearby waterfalls after another 30-minute hike. The effort was worthwhile—the falls were serene, and the scenery breathtaking. It felt like becoming one with nature. Soaking in the frigid water was akin to communing with Mother Earth. The chilly air and water nearly lulled us to sleep.

Well, I’m sure my sisters are completely wasted. Today was Pride in San Diego, and I know my sisters—when it’s time to drink, it’s time to drink. It’s the one thing I didn’t inherit from the Buenviajes: the desire to drink. There are few occasions when I don’t mind drinking, but they’re very rare. We have a month left before Ed leaves, and I think it’s starting to sink in for him and for all of us. It hit me a long time ago. I just hope Ed will be here for Bailey’s surgery. We’ve been monitoring his swelling, and there’s definitely quite a bit.

Daniel Radcliffe, aka Harry Potter, has grown up so fast, and he’s adorable! Matthew too, haha. The movie was fantastic, though I give it 4½ stars because they left out key details. Overall, it was great! I didn’t dress up, but I wore a Ravenclaw tie (even though I prefer Gryffindor). Might see it again in two weeks!

Pears and peanut butter attempt #2. This time, I have firm pears and my own jar of peanut butter for dipping, though it's crunchy rather than smooth—I think that makes a difference. I’m slightly perturbed, as I believed this was a healthy snack, but just noticed that per 100g (our jars are much smaller), there are 614 calories! Best not to dwell on it.  

Just returned from an evening at my old music teacher’s house—yes, I missed her, but I recorded it! Also discovered they’re airing repeats of series 9 every morning at 9:55. It was lovely seeing my friend—unusual but nice.

GOP faces criticism over recruitment tactics as naturalization ceremonies in Jacksonville are relocated following complaints that GOP activists registered new citizens as Republicans. By Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy, the Jacksonville citizenship ceremony appeared routine, with nearly 200 people becoming new Americans. Before the event concluded on June 29, an immigration official encouraged attendees to visit a voter registration table—a common sight at such ceremonies. However, this table stood out: Republican volunteers distributed forms with the party affiliation box pre-checked, automatically enrolling new voters into the GOP. Linda Cross, present to witness her husband Dario Cruz’s oath, found the situation suspicious.

I liked the idea of that as an offense—perhaps it could’ve been a way to avoid being burned as a witch. As a non-American blogger, I’ve hesitated to engage in certain discussions, especially those about flags. But since I initiated the topic (not the flag-burning), I should probably weigh in. First, I believe outlawing flag-burning is absurd. The moment you grant any symbol automatic reverence and protection, you take a small but dangerous step toward totalitarianism. Symbols are fickle—they don’t inherently represent anything; their meaning lies in perception and interpretation.

Prom is tomorrow... I hope it’s going to be fun. That’s all I ask. Rob arrives May 14th... Yeah, three weeks from today... Oh god, I think I’m giving myself an ulcer just thinking about it. But I’m so excited to see him—scared too, but très excited. The Leafs played last night... But since Calgary was also playing and I’m on the West Coast... I had to watch their game instead. It’s alright, I guess... Considering the Leafs lost, which makes me sad. But Philly’s a good team... So... I still have bragging rights—they went further than the damn Canucks! Today’s a crazy day...

1. Everyone has a favorite movie or series—mine is the *Evil Dead* franchise (if it wasn’t obvious). I own one of the largest collections of memorabilia from the series.  
2. Can you play an instrument? Bass guitar—and yes, I rock out.  
3. Biggest money-wasting vice? Compulsive DVD purchases or splurging on new tech.  
4. Any phobias, allergies, or compulsions? None, none, and I must arrange my cash from least to greatest at all times.  
5. How much wood could a woodchuck chuck? Because I said so.

Hello, I saw *Troy* tonight with my family... I wasn’t impressed. Too tired to delve into specifics, but it had potential. Too much effort went into the set (which was stunning) and not enough into crafting a cohesive tone or theme. It retold the story but lacked depth, and I didn’t gain much from it. Character development was weak. The score felt like a poor imitation of *Gladiator*—which used haunting vocals effectively to enhance its gripping narrative.

Today, I miss my sister terribly—it feels strange not having her around, even if she did irritate me (just kidding!). Though it was only for a week, her presence was truly felt, in the best way. On a deeper level, she was my connection to family back home. Oh, how I miss them all. Tomorrow begins a new term. How did the holidays pass so quickly?

Mutation-based fuzzing typically uses an initial set of non-crashing seed inputs (a corpus) to generate new test cases through mutation. To address this, fuzzers employ distillation tools (e.g., afl-cmin) that select the smallest seed subset triggering the same instrumentation coverage as the full corpus. Minimizing seed count and cumulative size is widely believed to improve fuzzing efficiency—a claim we systematically investigate. We present findings from 34+ CPU-years of fuzzing with five distillation methods to evaluate their bug-finding impact in real-world software.

"In this paper, we examine multi-agent discrete-event systems under partial observation. The agents can be grouped such that each group shares isomorphic state transition structures, allowing them to be relabeled into a common template. Using this template, we design a scalable supervisor whose state size and computational cost remain unaffected by the number of agents. This supervisor, under partial observation, requires no recomputation even as agents are added or removed. We extend prior results by proposing sufficient conditions for safety and maximal permissiveness of the least restrictive scalable supervisor at the template level. Electric network frequency (ENF) fluctuations serve as a powerful tool in multimedia forensics. An efficient ENF estimation method is proposed, utilizing temporal windowing based on the filter-bank Capon spectral estimator. A Gohberg-Semencul factorization of the model covariance matrix is employed, leveraging its Toeplitz structure. Additionally, this approach introduces, for the first time in ENF analysis, a non-rectangular temporal window prior to spectral estimation. Krylov matrices enable fast matrix inversion. The proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art techniques in ENF estimation for 1-second power recordings. In speech recordings, it achieves high accuracy with improved time complexity.

The direpack package introduces a set of modern statistical dimension reduction techniques to the Python ecosystem as a unified and consistent toolkit. The included methods fall into three categories: projection pursuit, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust M-estimators. Additionally, regularized regression estimators based on reduced dimensions are provided, spanning from principal component regression to sparse partial robust M regression. The package also offers classical and robust preprocessing utilities, such as generalized spatial signs, along with dedicated plotting and cross-validation tools. Designed to align with the scikit-learn API, direpack seamlessly integrates into statistical and machine learning pipelines within that framework.

The nonlinear fluorescence emission has been widely used for high-resolution optical imaging. Here, we investigated the fluorescence anomalous saturating effect in nitrogen vacancy defects in diamond. Fluorescence reduction was observed under high-power laser excitation, enhancing emission nonlinearity and altering the spatial frequency distribution of the image. A differential excitation protocol extracted high spatial frequency information. By modulating the laser power, imaging resolution improved by approximately 1.6 times compared to confocal microscopy. Given the experimental simplicity and straightforward data processing, we anticipate this method will enhance spatial resolution for sensing and biological labeling with solid-state defects.

When random effects are correlated with sample design variables, standard methods that use individual survey weights (inversely proportional to inclusion probabilities) to form a pseudo-likelihood fail to provide asymptotically unbiased inference. We propose a weight-exponentiated formulation for the random effects distribution, ensuring unbiased hyperparameter estimation. Our approach outperforms frequentist methods relying on numerical integration, as only the Bayesian method achieves both design-unbiased estimation and population-consistent inference. Simulations and a business establishment survey demonstrate our method's versatility across models and sampling designs. This work culminates recent efforts integrating survey estimation with Bayesian modeling, bridging two distinct yet rich sub-fields.

Low-symmetry 2D materials—such as ReS₂ and ReSe₂ monolayers, black phosphorus, group-IV monochalcogenides, and borophene—exhibit more intricate atomic structures than the honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. Their reduced symmetries lead to inhomogeneous electron, optical, valley, and spin responses, along with novel properties like ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, strong nonlinear optical effects, photogalvanic responses, and superconductivity. Unique electronic topologies, nonlinear elasticity, and structural phase transitions also arise from low symmetry. The "Beyond Graphene: Low-Symmetry and Anisotropic 2D Materials" special topic highlights recent experimental and theoretical advances in these emerging materials.

Orientational dynamics in the isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematic polymer with mesogenic and functional side groups were investigated using Kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy. For the first time, results revealed that in a mesogenic polymer—unlike low-molecular-weight mesogens—the relaxation of electric birefringence above the nematic-isotropic transition temperature can be described by multiple exponential processes, with two dominant contributions. These primary processes alternate within a temperature range of approximately fifty degrees. Dielectric spectroscopy further identified two orientational relaxation mechanisms: one arising from side-group rotation and the other linked to main-chain segment motion.

Deep hashing methods have demonstrated strong retrieval accuracy and efficiency in large-scale image retrieval. Optimizing discrete hash bits remains a key focus in these methods. A common strategy is to use activation functions like $\operatorname{sigmoid}(\cdot)$ or $\operatorname{tanh}(\cdot)$, minimizing quantization loss to approximate discrete values. However, this approach can trap hash bits in the wrong saturated regions of activation functions, preventing recovery. We term this issue the "dead bits problem (dbp)." Additionally, existing quantization loss worsens dbp. To address this, we propose a simple yet effective gradient amplifier applied before activation functions to mitigate dbp.

We examine the phenomenology of a hypercharge-zero SU(2) triplet scalar, motivated by two-step electroweak symmetry-breaking. We explore scenarios where the triplet is either stable (contributing to dark matter) or decays via Higgs mixing. The stable case is constrained by LHC disappearing-track searches and direct detection experiments, while the decaying case faces limits from multilepton collider searches. A two-step phase transition with a stable triplet and negative quadratic term is ruled out by direct detection, whereas an unstable triplet below $230\ \mathrm{GeV}$ is excluded at $95\%$ confidence.

This paper demonstrates that the eccentric debris rings observed around the stars Fomalhaut and HD 202628 are narrower than predicted by the standard eccentric planet perturbation model (often termed "pericenter glow"). According to this model, an initially circular and narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis \(a\) gains an eccentricity \(e_f\) via secular perturbations from an eccentric planet after gas disc dispersal, producing a belt of width \(2ae_f\). A slight modification suggests narrower belts could form if planetesimals are initially eccentric, possibly due to earlier planet perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary phase. Alternatively, primordial eccentricity might arise from disc instabilities, independent of planets.

An electron is typically considered to possess only one form of kinetic energy, but could it exhibit additional types due to its spin, charge, or interactions with other electrons? In one dimension (1D), the physics of interacting electrons is well described at low energies by the Tomonaga-Luttinger liquid (TLL) model, yet experimental observations beyond this linear regime remain scarce. Here, we present measurements of many-body modes in 1D gated wires using tunneling spectroscopy. We identify two distinct Fermi seas at high energies, linked to spin and charge excitations, alongside the appearance of three additional 1D "replica" modes that intensify as wire length decreases. The effective interaction strength is tuned by varying 1D inter-subband screening by over 45%.

Spintronic nanodevices exhibit ultrafast nonlinear dynamics and recurrence behaviors on a nanosecond scale, enabling spintronic reservoir computing (RC) systems. Here, two physical RC systems—one based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (MSM) and another using 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNOs)—were modeled for image classification and nonlinear dynamic system prediction, respectively. Micromagnetic simulations of MSM and STNO responses to current pulses demonstrate that an RC system with a single MSM achieves outstanding performance in handwritten digit recognition. Furthermore, a physical RC system comprising 24 STNOs effectively solves complex nonlinear dynamic problems, as validated by second-order nonlinear dynamic system and NARMA10 tasks.

Ranking algorithms play a vital role in online platforms, from search engines to recommender systems. In this paper, we uncover an unexpected consequence of popularity-based rankings: the fewer the items sharing a signal, the greater their collective share of traffic. This few-get-richer effect arises when distinct item classes are limited (e.g., left-leaning vs. right-leaning news sources) and rankings depend on popularity. We analytically show this effect occurs when users favor top-ranked items and exhibit diverse class preferences. Through simulations, we examine how the effect's intensity varies with contextual and behavioral assumptions. We also validate our predictions experimentally in an online study. These findings offer critical insights into misinformation spread.

Weight pruning is widely recognized as a simple yet effective method to reduce redundancy in deep neural networks (DNNs), enabling acceleration across platforms. By leveraging carefully designed patterns, our pruning method consistently enhances accuracy and improves feature extraction across diverse DNN architectures and datasets. Additionally, our framework integrates pattern library extraction, selection, pruning, and weight training seamlessly. This approach naturally aligns with compiler optimizations, ensuring efficient DNN execution on mobile platforms.

Difference-in-differences analysis with a control group that differs significantly from a treated group risks bias due to historical events affecting the groups differently. For our analysis of MRM's effect on mortality, we developed a better-matched control group and obtained a 95% confidence interval spanning substantial adverse effects, no effect, and minor beneficial effects.

When building models to summarize clinical data for simulations, it is essential to assess their ability to reproduce the data. This can be achieved through visual predictive checks (VPC), which involve: (1) simulating multiple replicates of the original study using the model, (2) computing key estimates for each simulated dataset, and (3) comparing their distribution with the original estimate. This approach is a versatile and generally straightforward method. Here, we apply it to time-to-event data and examine the specific case where a time-varying covariate is unknown or cannot be approximated post-event.

Novel concepts, perspectives, and challenges in measuring and controlling open quantum systems through sequential schemes are presented. (iii) optimally reconstructing environmental noise spectral density by orthogonalizing filter functions in the frequency domain for quantum-sensor design. These advancements will improve our ability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, driving progress in quantum science and technology.
